text: Ah the Genesis, my old friend. Many a night were spent with Sonic, King's bounty, Cyberball, and Altered Beast. Still have em all too
author: Gouzaku Fuwachi

text:
All I had as a kid was Sonic 1, King's Bounty, Cyberball, Altered Beast, and M1 Abrams Battle Tank for the Genesis, and for the SNES I only had Super Mario World and A Link to the Past.

Luckily, I'm one of those people who would never sell/trade in games or systems, so i still have them all. Slightly dustier and worn, but still working fine. :)
author: Gouzaku Fuwachi

text: Nope, still work fine. Half of my SNES got a yellow tint, so it's two tone White-Yelllow now, but thats it
author: Gouzaku Fuwachi

text: I remember when my friend and I set out to beat this game no matter what. It took us a whole afternoon to beat this game, with limited lives and continues. I seem to remember us beating it with only 2 lives left to spare.
author: Jamey C.

text: 1988 marked the release of the Sega Genesis and Altered Beast was its pack-in game. That is, until Sega decided to replace it with a little game called Sonic the Hedgehog in 1991. A very wise decision since there's no need to remind how important Sonic ended up being for the company. It also didn't help that this was not a great beat 'em up (and an inferior Arcade port); I personally never liked it. Still, it garnered a bit of a cult status and it did have some impressive parallax scrolling at the time. This theme is very nice too.
author: SupraDarky

text: SupraDarky actually the Genesis was released in 1989; it was the Japanese Mega Drive that was released in 1988
